page.title: 16ECOLOGY OF THE STUDY AREA
page.content: Being a rural / farming community the study area is rich in wildlife -the hedgerow still forming an important field and farm boundary.Hedgehogs,grey squirrels,rabbits and moles are locally common,whilst stoats,weasles and hares are fairly common.A variety of birds of prey can be seen,kestrel being most common,sparrow hawk and buzzard are frequently recorded.The peregrine falcon and merlin are rare visitors.The little and tawny owls are breeders,however there are no records of barn owls in the study area during the past 5 years.In areas of mixed woodland nuthatches,tree creepers, wrens,coal tits,hedge sparrows,and willow tits are frequently observed. Blue tits,great tits,greenfinches, robins,house sparrows,starlings,song and mistle thrushes are frequent visitors to the winter garden table.
